thread.section_title: Foreign and national political news and analysis - San Francisco Chronicle
thread.title: Alaska department moving away from 'bridge to nowhere'
thread.title_full: Alaska department moving away from 'bridge to nowhere' - San Francisco Chronicle

author: Becky Bohrer, Associated Press
title: Alaska department moving away from 'bridge to nowhere'
text: Photo: Hall Anderson, AP File - In this July 17, 2003, file photo, the Ketchikan airport ferry Bob Ellis leaves the airport loceated on Gravina Island in Ketchikan, Alaska. Alaska’s so-called bridge to nowhere, which became a poster child for congressional earmarks, appears dead. State transportation department officials have spurned the idea of building a bridge to connect the southeast Alaska community of Ketchikan to its airport on a neighboring island. The state instead is endorsing the continued use of a ferry to get people to and from the airport. Construction costs would be about $23 million to update terminals and waiting areas. (Hall Anderson/Ketchikan Daily News via AP, File) File - In this July 17, 2003, file photo, the Ketchikan airport... JUNEAU, Alaska (AP) — Alaska's so-called bridge to nowhere, derided by critics as an example of congressional earmarks run amok, appears dead. File - In this July 17, 2003, file photo, the Ketchikan airport ferry Bob Ellis leaves the airport loceated on Gravina Island in Ketchikan, Alaska. The state instead is endorsing the continued use of a ferry to get people to and from the airport. Construction costs would be about $23 million to update terminals and waiting areas.
